Award.AwardTitle: Organizational Boundary Spanning in Large Collaborative Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increasingly, the pursuit of scientific discovery is being fulfilled not by individuals working in isolation, but rather by teams of individuals, or even networks of teams, working together to achieve a common objective. One major reason for this shift toward larger social networks as solvers of scientific problems is that problems are becoming increasingly complex and require different areas of expertise, making them too difficult for individuals to solve alone. Although there is great potential for the use of networks of individuals and teams in the pursuit of science, they require individuals to navigate through the interpersonal complexities of those networks. Such complexities are especially evident when one considers that individuals, in order to accomplish their work, may be connected or tied not only to others working in the same organization, but also to others working in different organizations. With this in mind, the purpose of this research is to understand how the quantity, quality, and composition of individuals' internal and external ties influence performance in a scientific context, with a particular emphasis on the ways in which external ties facilitate or hinder the effects of internal ties on performance. Understanding the joint influence of internal and external social network ties not only has the potential to promote the progress of science, but it also has implications for contexts outside of science collaboration. For example, the knowledge generated by this research will have implications for medical care, which is increasingly provided by networks of individuals and teams, business organizations, which are utilizing teams that transcend the boundaries of a single organization, and the military, with its use of Joint Forces and Combined Operations.

Via survey methodology, this research will generate data from a sample of scientists on their internal ties and external ties to other scientists working in particle physics facilities throughout the U.S. system of federally funded laboratories. To avoid limitations associated with self-report, the investigators will attempt to corroborate external ties reported by focal individuals with reports from internal ties. By identifying the quantity and quality of external, boundary spanning ties within the larger scientific ecosystem, the investigators will be able to examine issues such as the predictive validity of external ties relative to internal ties, whether external ties moderate the effects of internal ties on measures of performance, and whether the composition of external ties results in differential effects on performance, even when taking internal ties into account. In all, the initial identification of external ties, in conjunction with data on internal ties, represents an important extension because external ties may operate in a different manner relative to internal ties given that they may be characterized by (a) greater geographic dispersion, (b) higher levels of goal misalignment between teams, (c) less diversity because of the voluntary nature of external ties, and (d) less face-to-face interaction, depending upon the level of communication technology.

Performance_Institution.Name: Michigan State University Eli Broad College of Business

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

Historically, the organizational goals of cost effectiveness and efficiency were contrasted with the alternative goals of flexibility and innovativeness. However, organizations are increasingly under pressure to pursue both sets of goals simultaneously, and many organizations have responded to this pressure by turning to loosely structured multiteam systems. Nowhere is the pressure to simultaneously pursue goals related to both efficiency and innovation greater that than the fields of science. Thus, in the face of these dual pressures, the practice of science is being increasingly conducted by large team-based structures. Although there is great potential for the use of teams and larger team-based structures in the pursuit of science, it also has to be recognized that groups create their own unique problems that have been well documented in the applied social sciences over the last 60 years.

The purpose of the research proposed here is to determine how intra-organizational and inter-organizational boundary spanning ties affect individual and team performance in large collaborative scientific work. We studied these relationships employing a sample of scientists working in the field of particle physics as part of the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) and other particle physics facilities throughout the U.S. system of federally funded laboratories, using both traditional surveys as well as new wearable sensor technology.

Intellectual Merit:

The core findings associated with this work can be broken down into both methodological and substantive contributions. First, in terms of methods, we have been able to document the strengths and weaknesses associated with wearable sensors when it comes to measuring human interaction patterns for both research and applied purposes. The major weaknesses are lack of accuracy due to hardware limitations and attachment issues when it comes to sensors such as microphones, accelerometers, and infra-red sensors.

We did find, however, that Bluetooth sensors showed a great deal of potential for measuring human interaction patterns. We were able to demonstrate that BT-generated relational measures (a) show convergent validity with traditional self-reports of relational data and coded video data, (b) display discriminant validity with respect to qualitative differences in the nature of alternative relationships (i.e., advice versus friendship), (c) document predictive validity with respect to job performance, (d) provide incremental validity to self-reports when it comes to the accuracy of retrospective reports of behavior and (e) decompose variance in network-related measures into meaningful within and between unit variability over time. This last finding is revolutionary in its implications for future research because it allows fine-grained temporal assessment of interaction patterns (e.g., assessing daily social networks) that could never be achieved with traditional survey techniques.

In terms of substantive findings, our most powerful and interesting set of results were associated with the relationship between role performance and formal number of lateral formal workplace relationships prescribed by this organization. These findings contribute to research in organizational design by examining the transformation from bureaucratic to post-bureaucratic organizational forms. Consistent with the known advantages of bureaucratic structures that limit lateral relationships, we found that the number of lateral formal workplace relationships was negatively related to job performance.

However, when it came to informal relationships, a different pattern emerged. Specifically, our research suggested that individuals who engaged in a large number of informal open-ended boundary spanning relationships (i.e., where all members of a triad are not reciprocally linked), whether based on task-oriented or friendship, did not experience any negative outcomes from these activities. In contrast, there were some benefits attributable to having (a) a moderate number of open-ended task-oriented bridges, and (b) a small number of closed friendship bridges (i.e., where all members of a triad are reciprocally linked), The costs of closed informal activity were evident, however, when the number of closed bridges exceeded the apex of their respective inverted-U relationships. Taken together, these results suggest that there are limits to what can be accomplished by the “teaming” ( or over-teaming) of work that results from the formation of too many formal and closed informal lateral ties.  

Broader Impacts:

A recent national Research Council report noted that while the increasing size of team-based research projects can bring greater scientific expertise and more advanced instrumentation to a research question, it also increases the time required for communication and coordination of work, and thus, if these challenges are not recognized and addressed, projects may fail to achieve their scientific goals. Beyond the fields of science, however, one also sees that medical care is also increasingly provided by multiteam systems, and many business organizations are also characterized by team-based structures where the groups transcend the boundaries of a single organization. Finally, the importance of informal links that tie together teams is also evident in military contexts such as Joint Forces or Combined Operations, and hence our results have broad implications for collaborative work outside of science.
